page.title: 7.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will use your knowledge of geometric patterns to create tables and graphs that will represent the area of a garden.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Create drawings, tables, and graphs that represent the area of a garden.
  • Recognize a situation represented by a graph that increases and then decreases.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.1.1: Noticing New Patterns of Change
  • 7.1.2: The Relationship Between Length and Area
    • 7.1.2: Self Check
    • 7.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.1.3: Plotting Measurements
    • 7.1.3: Self Check
    • 7.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.1.4: The Input and Output of a Function

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.1.5: Practice
  • 7.1.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.1.1: Noticing New Patterns of Change
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity


Look at the patterns in the three tables. What do you notice? What do you wonder?

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

0

2

5

3

10

4

15

5

20

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

3

2

6

3

12

4

24

5

48

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

8

2

11

3

10

4

5

5

–4


Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers:

Things you may notice:

  • The \(x\)-values are \(1\), \(2\), \(3\), \(4\), and \(5\) in all three tables.
  • In the first two tables, the \(y\)-values increase, while in the third table, they increase and then decrease.
  • The \(y\)-values in the first table are all multiples of \(5\), and they grow linearly. In the second table, the \(y\)-values grow by a factor of \(2\) each time \(x\) increases by \(1\). In the third table, there isn’t an obvious pattern in how the \(y\)-values change.

Things you may wonder:

  • Is there a rule for the relationship in the third table?
  • Will the \(y\)-values in the third table continue to decrease, or will they increase again at some point?
  • What would the third relationship look like if graphed?

page.title: 7.1.2: The Relationship Between Length and Area
page.contents:
Activity

Noah has 50 meters of fencing to completely enclose a rectangular garden in the backyard.


  1. Draw some possible diagrams of Noah’s garden. Label the length and width of each rectangle.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Your answers will vary. Did you consider organizing your lengths, widths, and areas into a table? For example:

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

5

20

100

10

15

150

12

13

156

12.5

12.5

156.25

18

7

126

20

5

100

24

1

24


  1. Find the length and width of a rectangle that would produce the largest possible area. Explain why you think that pair of length and width gives the largest possible area.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When the length and width are each 12.5 meters, the area is the largest (156.25 square meters). A table shows that as the rectangular shape gets closer and closer to being a square, the area gets larger.

page.title: 7.1.2: Self Check
page.contents: Sonya has 70 meters of fencing to surround a rectangular garden. What is the largest possible area that can be enclosed, in square meters?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the measurement of the length and the width for the largest possible area. The answer is 306.25.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the sum of the width and length of the rectangle with the largest possible area. The answer is 306.25.
That’s correct! Check yourself: A square has the largest possible area with a length of 17.5 and a width of 17.5. Area of a rectangle is length times width.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the result of a length of 35 and width of 35. This would require 140 meters of fencing. The answer is 306.25.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Largest Possible Area

Tyrel is enclosing a grassy area for his goats. He has 80 feet of fencing and wants to make a rectangular enclosed area. What are the dimensions of the enclosure with the largest possible area?

First, make a table with possible length and width dimensions and their areas. Remember, each \(2l+2w=80\) and \(A=lw\).

Length 

Width

Area

5

35

175

10

30

300

15

25

375

20

20

400

25

15

375

30

10

300

35

5

175

Notice that the closer the rectangle is to a square, the larger the area.

The largest area occurs when the length and width are both 20 feet for an area of 400 square feet.

Try It: Largest Possible Area


Elena has 100 feet of fencing to make a rectangular pen for her cow. What is the largest possible area she can make with this amount of fencing?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the largest possible area:

Make a table with possible dimensions:

Length

Width

Area

10

40

80

20

30

600

25

25

625

30

20

600

40

10

80

Notice the closer you are to a square, the larger the area.

The largest possible area is 625 square feet.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.1.3: Plotting Measurements
page.contents:
Activity



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Plot some values for the length and area of the garden with perimeter 50 meters on the coordinate plane.

Use your table, or here is a sample table of values if you need one:

Values for a Rectangular Garden with a Perimeter of 50 Meters

Length (meters)

Area (square meters)

5

100

10

150

12

156

12.5

156.25

18

126

20

100

24

24

Be sure to label your axes. Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:



  1. What do you notice about how the plotted points increase and decrease?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

At first, the area grows as the length increases, but then it decreases. Also, the area increases more and more slowly as the length increases.



  1. The points \((3, 66)\) and \((22, 66)\) each represent the length and area of the garden. Plot these two points on a coordinate plane, if you haven’t already done so. What do these points mean in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The point \((3, 66)\) means that if the length of the garden is 3 meters, then the area is 66 square meters. This is right because the width is 22 meters and \(3 \cdot 22=66\). The point \((22, 66)\) means that the length of the garden is 22 meters, so its width is 3 meters, and the area is again 66 square meters.



  1. Could the point \((1, 25)\) represent the length and area of the garden?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The point \((1, 25)\) cannot represent the length and area of the garden. If the length of the garden is 1 meter, the width would be 24 meters, so the area is 24 square meters, not 25 square meters.


Video: The Meaning of Points on a Graph

Watch the following video to learn more about the meaning of points on a graph.



Extending Your Thinking

  1. What happens to the area when you interchange the length and width? For example, compare the areas of a rectangle of length 11 meters and width 14 meters with a rectangle of length 14 meters and width 11 meters.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The area stays the same if the length and width are interchanged because the area is the product of the length and the width.

  1. What patterns would you notice if you were to plot more length and area pairs on the graph?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Many of the areas would come with two different pairs: for example, 100 comes from the pair \((5, 100)\) and also from the pair \((20, 100)\) because a rectangle with length 5 meters and width 20 meters is the same as a rectangle with length 20 meters and width 5 meters. Using a different length and corresponding width, the 156 comes from the pair \((12, 156)\) and also from the pair \((13, 156)\). The points on the graph would have reflectional symmetry about the line \(x=12.5\).

page.title: 7.1.3: Self Check
page.contents: The graph below shows a rectangle’s side length and its area. What is true about the point \((3, 21)\)?

answer.answer_text: The width of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(x\)-coordinate represents the length, not the width. The answer is the length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

answer.answer_text: The length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The \(x\)-axis represents the side length, which would be the \(x\)-coordinate of 3 meters.

answer.answer_text: It is not possible to find the width of the rectangle when the length is 3 meters.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Working backward, the width would be 7 meters. The answer is the length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

answer.answer_text: The area of the rectangle is 3 square meters.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(x\)-coordinate represents the length, not the area. The answer is the length of the rectangle is 3 meters, and the area is 21 square meters.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Determining the Meaning of a Point on a Graph

The graph below shows the relationship between a rectangle’s side length and area.

What does the point \((7, 28)\) mean in the situation?

The \(x\)-axis represents the length of the rectangle in inches. So, when \(x=7\), the rectangle has a side length of 7 inches.

The \(y\)-axis represents the area of the rectangle. So, when \(y=28\), the rectangle has an area of 28 square inches.

This also means the rectangle has a width of 4 inches since \(7 \times 4=28\).

Try It: Determining the Meaning of a Point on a Graph


Using the same graph above, determine the meaning of the point \((3, 24)\) and the width of the rectangle.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine the meaning of the point \((3, 24)\) and the width of the rectangle:

Since the \(x\)-axis is the length of the rectangle in inches, \(x=3\) represents the length of the rectangle is 3 inches. Since the \(y\)-axis represents the area in square inches, the area of the rectangle is 24 square inches.

This means the width of the rectangle must be 8 inches since \(3 \times 8 = 24\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.1.4: The Input and Output of a Function
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A rectangular yard is enclosed by 100 meters of fencing. The table shows some possible values for the length and width of the yard.

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

10

40

400

20

30

25

25

625

35

15

525

40


  1. Complete the table with the missing values.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

10

40

400

20

30

600

25

25

625

35

15

525

40

10

400

The missing value in the second row is 600. The missing values in the last row are 10 and 400.



  1. If the values for length and area are plotted, what would the graph look like?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The points would form a stretched out upside-down U shape, or an arch.



  1. How is the relationship between the length and the area of the rectangle different from other kinds of relationships we’ve seen before?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

As one quantity increases, the other quantity first increases and then decreases, instead of always increasing or always decreasing.

page.title: 7.1.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here are a few pairs of positive numbers whose sum is 50.

Enter your answer here.

Row

First number

Second number

Product

a

1

49

b

2

48

c

10

40

    1. Find the product in Row a.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1 times 49 is 49.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.1.2–7.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 49. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Find the product in Row b.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 2 times 48 is 96.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.1.2–7.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 96. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Find the product in Row c.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 10 times 40 is 400.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.1.2–7.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 400. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following table to answer questions 2–5.

Here are some lengths and widths of a rectangle whose perimeter is 20 meters.

Row

Length (meters)

Width (meters)

Area (square meters)

a

1

9

b

3

7

c

5

d

7

e

9

  1. Complete the Width column of the table.

    1. Width in Row c

Enter your answer here.

Correct! If the length is 5, the width must be 5.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Width in Row d

Enter your answer here.

Correct! If the length is 7, the width must be 3.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Width in Row e

Enter your answer here.

Correct! If the length is 9, the width is 1.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Complete the Area column of the table. What do you notice about the areas?

    Enter your answer here.

    1. Area in Row a

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1 times 9 is 9.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 9. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Area in Row b

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 3 times 7 is 21.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 21. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Area in Row c

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 5 times 5 is 25.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 25. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Area in Row d

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 7 times 3 is 21.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 21. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Area in Row e

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1 times 9 is 9.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 9. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Without calculating, predict whether the area of the rectangle will be greater than or less than 25 square meters if the length is 5.25 meters.

Correct! When the length is 5.25, the width will be 4.75, so it can be estimated that the product of those numbers will be less than 25.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is less than. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Plot the points for length and area from your table. Do the values change in a linear way? Do they change in an exponential way?

Correct! As the length increases, the area increases then decreases.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.1.3–7.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is not linear and not exponential. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 6–8.

Copies of a book are arranged in a stack. Each copy of a book is 2.1 cm thick.

Row

Copies of book

Stack height in cm

a

0

b

1

c

2

d

3

e

4

  1. Complete the table.
    1. Stack height in Row a

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When there are 0 books, there is no stack height.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Stack height in Row b

Enter your answer here.

Correct! One book has a height of 2.1 cm.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2.1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Stack height in Row c

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Two books have a stack height of 2.1 cm times 2.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4.2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Stack height in Row d

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Three books have a stack height of 2.1 cm times 3.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 6.3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Stack height in Row e

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Four books have a stack height of 2.1 cm times 4.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 8.4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the difference in the height of the stack of books when a new copy of the book is added?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 2.1

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2.1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. How high is a stack of \(b\) books, in centimeters?

Correct! Each book is 2.1 cm, so multiply that by the number of books in the stack.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((2.1)b\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.1.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Create drawings, tables, and graphs that represent the area of a garden.
  • Recognize a situation represented by a graph that increases and then decreases.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.1.1: Noticing New Patterns of Change
    • In this activity, you determined patterns in tables based on how the \(y\)-values changed as the \(x\)-values changed.
  • 7.1.2: The Relationship Between Length and Area
    • In this activity, you examined different combinations of lengths and widths of a rectangle and their respective areas given an amount of fencing. You realized that the closer the rectangle was to a square, the larger the area.
    • 7.1.2: Self Check
    • 7.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.1.3: Plotting Measurements
    • In this activity, you looked at how a function that wasn’t linear or exponential changed by increasing and then decreasing.
    • 7.1.3: Self Check
    • 7.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.1.4: The Input and Output of a Function
    • In this activity, you completed a table where values again increased and then decreased, rather than always increasing or always decreasing like in linear and exponential functions.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.1.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
